data.text:
This is a list of all the CDs and most of the vinyl records and pre-recorded audiocassettes that I own. (I inherited all my parents’ records, but they’re in storage, so not listed.)

Albums are listed alphabetically by artist, and chronologically within the artist’s section (based on when originally recorded/released–not composed). Opera, musical theatre, and soundtracks are under the composer’s last name. Compilations (including soundtracks without an original score or featured songwriter) are under the name of a compiler/producer, or by title or company if no person or persons are clearly credited. Classical albums by one composer are usually under the composer’s name, but some exceptions have been made with star conductors/performers, who are always treated as the primary artist when performing works by multiple composers. A parenthetical asterisk ((*)), indicates copies for sale. The symbol [v] indicates vinyl, and [c] indicates PRE-RECORDED cassette. All others are CDs. A [d] indicates that I have the album on CD in addition to another format.

I try to credit every singer and musician possible (but not the entire staff), but I’m not always disciplined enough to type it all out, or the information isn’t on the printed materials. When a composer conducts his or her own work, I don’t restate the name. Parenthetical names are composer credits. An addition sign (+) indicates that the main artist (or at least one band member) has composed some of the content. Most links take you to cross-references unless the main artist name. I have also been careful with eponymous people: there are two different Gene Kellys, two Julie Andrewses, two (possibly three) different Brian Mays, and two Colin Davises mentioned here, for example.

These are all (most of?) the CDs, and most vinyl (all vinyl currently in my apartment–I had my brother put all the vinyl I left and all those owned by my parents in storage in Indianapolis) and most cassettes I own as of 16 July 2023.
